image.altText: Cheese on a wooden board in the sunlight.

props.synopsis: For a community as small as that on King Island, the looming shutdown of a dairy factory will "affect everything", with locals still processing the news a business with 120 years of history is soon to shut down for good — unless a saviour can be found.

title.children: 'It'll affect everything': Island community reeling over shock announcement of 120-year-old King Island dairy's end

image.altText: Jim Chalmers wears a navy suit, looking solemnly off camera.

props.synopsis: With the national accounts this week showing the economy barely registering a pulse, more oxygen was expended on accusing the treasurer of being mean to the Reserve Bank than on what is happening in the economy.

title.children: Instead of studying the tectonic shifts of the economy, we're burning oxygen on the treasurer being 'mean' to the RBA

image.altText: A map showing Muswellbrook NSW.

props.synopsis: The Seismology Research Centre has recorded a magnitude-4.5 earthquake near Muswellbrook.

title.children: Earthquake hits NSW Hunter Region weeks after two similar events

image.altText: Mother and child hug anonymous generic

props.synopsis: Amber feared her daughter was being sexually abused by her ex. A family court judge said she was projecting her own experiences onto her daughter, and she lost custody.

title.children: Amber's sister made a 'malicious' report to child safety about her parenting. It found its way into her family court case

image.altText: Danny Gibson smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: The mayor of Tasmania's second-largest city says there is no legal mechanism available to him to remove an elected representative from council, as councillors respond to allegations raised against colleague Danny Gibson.

title.children: 'Very difficult day for councillors': Launceston Council discusses allegations against former mayor Danny Gibson at meeting

image.altText: A peninsula with rolling slopes and bays.

props.synopsis: The South Arm Peninsula is one of Tasmania's driest pieces of land. The Morrison Coalition government gave developers $5 million to pipe treated effluent there to help build a golf course. The pipe is being installed, but legal fights are continuing.

title.children: Court case clouds plan for publicly funded water pipeline to dry peninsula and golf course

image.altText: Feral piglets run through the undergrowth.

props.synopsis: The Central Coast Council says the pigs originated from a private property and there are now about 150 roaming a farming community. The council says it has limited powers to deal with the problem and is calling on the state government to strengthen laws.

title.children: 'They will eat crops': Roaming pigs hogging ratepayer resources in Tasmania's north-west

image.altText: Perth Mint gold

props.synopsis: Gold has been relentlessly surging to new records. So what's behind the recent demand?

title.children: Why gold is surging and what it tells us about global stability

image.altText: Dr Saul Karnovsky in his office at Curtin University in Perth looking and writing notes.

props.synopsis: An education researcher warns burnout is driving teachers out of the profession in droves and staff shortages in schools across the country next year will be far worse than authorities are predicting.

title.children: 'It's basically having no life': Teachers leaving schools in droves due to burnout

image.altText: Rainbow Flag

props.synopsis: The 2026 census questions on gender and sexual orientation that have been at the centre of a political brawl for the past week have been revealed to the ABC.

title.children: LGBTQI+ questions scrapped from census revealed

image.altText: A composite image showing Wayne Swan handing down the budget in 2008 and Jim Chalmers handing down this budget.

props.synopsis: Labor frustrations with Jim Chalmers's mild-mannered, hand-picked RBA governor spilled into the open this week.

title.children: A pair of Labor treasurers delivered a one-two 'punch' to the RBA this week. It was a strategy, not an accident.

image.altText: A man in a grey shirt holding a door frame with a shattered window.

props.synopsis: Bororen residents were told to "grab the essentials and leave" after a truck carrying chemicals exploded on a nearby highway. They returned to shattered windows, cracked ceilings and broken doors.

title.children: A chemical explosion rocked this quiet town, and residents are still reeling from the shockwave

image.altText: Donald Trump has a serious expression.

props.synopsis: A New York judge postpones Donald Trump's sentencing for his "hush money" crimes until after the upcoming US election.

title.children: Trump's sentencing in porn star 'hush money' case delayed until after election

image.altText: image of Israeli tank operating in Gaza

props.synopsis: The controversial "Hannibal Directive", which Israel says isn't named for the famous Carthaginian general who took poison rather than be captured by the Romans, was reportedly enacted after the October 7 Hamas attack, with revelations detailing attacks by IDF tanks and helicopters on homes and vehicles returning to Gaza.

title.children: The mysterious Israeli directive that might have cost lives during the country’s darkest day

image.altText: elderly people dance outside

props.synopsis: In response to an aging population and growing pressure on pensions, the Chinese Communist Party plans to raise the statutory retirement age – which currently stands as low as 50 years old for some workers.

title.children: 'Never popular': Beijing seeks to raise the country's low retirement age

image.altText: An FBI police vehicle

props.synopsis: US law enforcement officials says the 20-year-old Pakistan national "planned a terrorist attack in New York City around October 7th of this year with the stated goal of slaughtering, in the name of ISIS, as many Jewish people as possible".

title.children: Man charged with plotting mass shooting at US Jewish centre on anniversary of Hamas attack

image.altText: Elle Macpherson walks the runway for Ngali during the Melbourne Fashion Festival

props.synopsis: Not all voices carry in the same way; not everyone has clout: Macpherson does, and while she is right to say that she's entitled to tell her story, it's also true that it's dangerous to shout "fire" in a crowded theatre.

title.children: Elle is entitled to tell her cancer story. But it's also dangerous to shout 'fire' in a crowded theatre

image.altText: A composite image of a broadcasting tower with a sign reading "ten" and an image of a woman with blonde hair smiling.

props.synopsis: Network Ten reporter Tegan George's bid to sue her employer over trauma she says she suffered covering the bushfire season in 2019 and 2020 ends in a confidential settlement.

title.children: Network Ten reporter Tegan George reaches settlement with broadcaster over bushfire trauma

image.altText: Ben Hance celebrates breaking his world record at Paris Paralympics.

props.synopsis: Ben Hance defends his Paralympic crown from Tokyo, as 17-year-old Callum Simpson announced himself on the world stage with his first individual gold medal. Follow live

title.children: Hance and Simpson win gold as Aussie swimmers collect seven medals in the pool

image.altText: A man with a beard stands in front of the Australian War Memorial and looks into the camera.

props.synopsis: In the past two weeks, more than 200 current and former service personnel have pledged their brains to the Australian Veterans Brain Bank, after the ABC reported growing evidence of a link between mild traumatic brain injury associated with blast exposure and poor mental health and suicide.

title.children: Khalil served 34 years in the military. He has pledged his brain to science to help other veterans

image.altText: Man with grey hair wearing striped gray prison unifrom appears in court

props.synopsis: The father and son appeared in back-to-back hearings on Friday morning local time, with about 50 onlookers in the courtroom.

title.children: Father of Georgia school shooting suspect remanded in custody after appearing in court

image.altText: A close up of Taylor Swift wearing a black corset top and raising a glass at a football game.

props.synopsis: Earlier this year, Australian designer Dion Lee was making waves in the fashion world after his corset top was debuted by the most famous woman in the world. How did all go so wrong for this local brand?

title.children: Just months ago, Dion Lee was dressing Taylor Swift. How did it go so wrong for this Australian brand?

image.altText: A man wearing a military uniform looking on.

props.synopsis: Ukraine has managed to capture more territory in a month than Russia has in a year, but with troops stretched and Putin's forces closing in on a key transport hub, some are questioning whether Kyiv's surprise invasion of the Kursk region was a good idea.

title.children: Ukraine's invasion of Russia was seen by some as a masterstroke, but it might backfire

image.altText: Politicians sit on the lower house benches in a wide view capturing the entire lower house floor.

props.synopsis: Parliament is considering new laws to penalise bad behaviour inside the nation's seat of power. But how much has changed since Brittany Higgins's allegation of rape three years ago forced an upheaval?

title.children: Since Brittany Higgins's rape allegation, how much has parliament's culture really improved?

image.altText: Jack Ginnivan mimics drinking a can of beer

props.synopsis: Hawthorn forward Jack Ginnivan caused a stir when he was spotted at a pub 24 hours before his team's finals opener. It was an outing his senior coach was entirely on board with.

title.children: 'Enormously influential': Mitchell ticks off Jack Ginnivan's pre-finals pub visit, eccentric goal celebration in Hawks win

image.altText: Mark Nawaqanitawase leaps to catch the ball

props.synopsis: The Eels avoided the wooden spoon by thrashing Wests Tigers in the spoon bowl, before the Roosters beat the Rabbitohs after a magical debut score from Mark Nawaqanitawase.

title.children: Ex-Wallabies star scores stunner on debut as Roosters beat Rabbitohs, Eels win spoon bowl

image.altText: Woman with eyes closed, lying on yoga mat.

props.synopsis: Mindfulness is everywhere, and its backed by everyone from Gwyneth Paltrow to Buddhist practitioners and the US military. But what actually is it? And can it help us deal with stress, or should we be sceptical?

title.children: How mindfulness can be weaponised against the people it's meant to help

image.altText: Donald Trump and Kamala Harris speak into microphones in two side-by-side images.

props.synopsis: After plenty of haggling, the Donald Trump and Kamala Harris camps have agreed to some rules for the first presidential debate. But neither side is entirely happy.

title.children: The Trump-Harris debate rules have been released, and both sides are complaining

image.altText: Benji Marshall speaks to reporters

props.synopsis: A third consecutive wooden spoon is not cause for the Wests Tigers to stray off the path of a lengthy rebuild, according to coach and club legend Benji Marshall.

title.children: 'Time might not be on my side': Marshall won't accelerate Tigers' rebuild, even if it saves his job

image.altText: Long green stalks of grass in plastic pots for collecting data. In the background is blue clear sky.

props.synopsis: Weeds cost Australia's crop farming industry around $3.3 billion dollars each year, but a home-grown invention that crushes herbicide-resistant weed seeds could make that a problem of the past.

title.children: Farmer invents machinery that smashes 'bejesus' out of weed seeds

image.altText: a side profile of a man adjusting his tie before a TV interview

props.synopsis: South Australia's former Liberal leader David Speirs says a federal takeover of the state's branch should be 'seriously considered' but current leader Vincent Tarzia disagrees.

title.children: Former SA Liberal leader suggests federal takeover of state division

image.altText: A drone-shot of an industrial area, Techno Park Drive, with eight large fuel tanks sitting amongst residential houses.

props.synopsis: A council in Melbourne's west knew it could be making up to 50 people homeless when it ordered them to leave an affordable housing estate last year and contemplated not offering them any assistance at all, according to internal documents obtained by the ABC.

title.children: Council intended to 'extinguish' Techno Park residents' rights, documents show

image.altText: Portrait of a man against mountain ranges at sunset

props.synopsis: David Crust, who oversees the management of a million hectares of the Blue Mountains, says he's never seen the level of destruction wrought by the elements over the past five years.

title.children: Boom in nature tourism is increasing safety challenges for Blue Mountains, parks boss say

image.altText: An Aboriginal woman signs a document while sitting on a park bench next to a man.

props.synopsis: The federal government will pay up to $202 million to settle a historic stolen wages class action in the Northern Territory involving thousands of Indigenous workers and their relatives.

title.children: Commonwealth to pay up to $202m settlement in NT Indigenous stolen wages class action

image.altText: A sun setting behind a hilltop

props.synopsis: After more than 12 months of record-breaking heat this year and last, the 2024 summer period in the northern hemisphere shatters records to become the hottest yet.

title.children: Earth swelters through hottest August and northern summer on record
